name: FISHERIES
description:
The waters around Papua New Guinea contain large stocks of marine resources. Within the 200 mile economic zone are large varieties of fish, including migrating schools of tuna. Besides abundant tuna and other pelagic species, several other commercially important fish, shellfish, and sedentary species are found in Papua New Guinea's waters. More than 10,000 species of fish, molluscs and crustaceans have so far been identified.

 Coastal commercial fishing is based primarily on prawns, lobster and baramundi and a collection of sedentary fisheries resources, including beche-de-mer, trochus shells, pearl shell and green snail. The operations are carried out by small-scale commercial fishermen, who sell their product to a range of small to medium sized fish processing and marketing entrepreneurs. Sea cucumber is collected and processed for export. The trade in shells with lustrous interiors is small, but growing.

 

Domestic private investment in commercial fisheries in Papua New Guinea is small. Inland fish production is still very much underdeveloped, but commercial farming of trout and carp has been undertaken by a few farmers in the Highlands region of the country. The Papua New Guinea government is exploring avenues for the privatization of various aspects of its coastal fisheries programme.

 Private sector participation is encouraged in the areas of handling, processing and marketing of marine products, craft construction, repairs and maintenance, engine sales and ice and fishing equipment sales. The Government is also playing a key role in the management of the fishing industry. The long-term sustainability of the resources and the environmental impact are the key factors for the long-term sustainability, growth and development of the fisheries sector.

 

The major emphasis of the Government is the development of industrial and commercial fisheries which will help to provide the infrastructure necessary from small and medium scale fisheries development.

 

The PNG National Fisheries Authority is the primary regulatory and management body for the sector and it provides support and coordinate fishery development in the country. It also facilitates export certification and regulation and manages fisheries resources for sustainable growth.

name: FORESTRY
description:
The Papua New Guinea Forest Authority (PNGFA) is the government body responsible for monitoring and controlling the wood and forest-based industries and the management of PNG's forest resources.

 

There are three key arms of the forestry administration of PNG including the National Forest Board, respective Provincial Forest Management Committees and the National Forest Service. The respective Provincial Forest Management Committees contribute to the decisions relating to the management of the forest resource within the provinces. The Papua New Guinea Forest Industry Association Inc. (PNGFIA) promotes and protects the interest of the forest industry.

There are 39 million hectares of enclosed forest harbouring a wealth of timber species. Of these 39 million hectares, 15 million hectares of high quality tropical hardwoods are considered to be suitable for development. The State has acquired 12 million hectares from the 15 million hectares, of which 10 million hectares have been allocated under timber permits.

The Government is mindful of its obligations to environmental heritage when promoting the forest resource. Each major investment project is carefully evaluated in terms of its environmental impact and every effort is made to develop appropriate guidelines to meet the needs of both the local people and the investors.

 The Government's recognition of the value of rare and magnificent natural forest has resulted in major policy changes aimed at creating an environment for sustainable downstream processing activities. International markets are establishing requirements for all tropical wood products to come from forest plantations and afforested sourced areas. With Papua New Guinea reforming its forestry policy to meet the international requirements particularly in already clear felled areas and savanna grasslands, it will be well-equipped to provide sound and rewarding investment opportunities.

In the forestry sub-sector, products made of tropical hardwood attract top prices. Although markets do exist, few are efficiently supplied at present, so the ability to establish a constant customer supply will guarantee a permanent and high demand.
short_description: The Papua New Guinea Forest Authority (PNGFA) is the government body responsible for monitoring and controlling the wood and forest-based industries and the management of PNG's forest resources.

name: Infrastructure
description:
Investment in the Infrastructure Sector

The rehabilitation and maintenance of the transport infrastructure is an important priority for the national government, due to the crucial role that the transport infrastructure plays in facilitating improved access to goods and services. In recent years the Government has invested substantial budgetary support towards building and improving public infrastructure throughout the country, including regular maintenance and upkeep of the transport infrastructure.

Three sectors of infrastructure within the context of transport are presented beginning with the relevant policy frameworks (plans and vision) followed by a discussion of the sectors as follows: roads and road transport; maritime and inland water transport; and air transport.

 

Sector Profile in PNG

The vision of the transport sector by the Government is to have “a well-integrated, competitive, affordable, financially and environmentally sustainable transport system”. In order to achieve this vision a number of goals are to be achieved, amongst others, the following: “restore the national transport network; develop new infrastructure where economically viable and within financial and capacity constraints; bring 95% of the population within easy reach of all-weather transport access; and provide transport access to 95% or more of developable agricultural land”. To guide this vision and goal of the Government the Medium-Term Transport Plan (MTTP) and the National Transport Strategy (NTS) were formulated as a response to the overarching policy direction of Vision 2050, the Development Strategic Plan, the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), and the Medium-Term Development Plan (MTDP).

 

Roads

The roads in PNG have developed around the provincial centers of population, many of which are on the coast and linked nationally by coastal shipping. Local road networks have been developed from these coastal centers, along the coastal plains and upriver-valleys and over mountain passes to penetrate inland. The Highlands Region is landlocked, with the main centers connected by air, and this spurred the development of the Highlands Highway connecting the 7 inland provinces with the coast of PNGs main port of Lae. PNG’s subnational network of provincial and district roads total about 20,000 km and serves 85% of the rural population. However, rural roads often receive fewer financial and technical resources than national roads and many are deteriorating due to neglect. 

 

Maritime and Inland Water Transport

The existing policy that controls and regulates the number of coastal vessels trading on specific routes within PNG waters be reviewed with the intention of encouraging competition while maintaining strict controls over safety and security of all PNG registered vessels and monitoring the total number of vessels trading in these waters. The current practice of generally prohibiting overseas vessels from carrying domestic cargoes (carbotage) is also to be reviewed.

 

Civil Aviation

PNG’s aviation industry provides essential support for tourism, business, trade, and social cohesion. However, deteriorating infrastructure and constrained institutional capacity threaten the certification of many of PNG’s airports. The Civil Aviation Authority’s development plan provides a framework for addressing existing gaps, but the agency requires technical and financial support to implement them successfully. In support of the 2009 Ministerial Policy statement, the Civil Aviation Policy 2000 was prepared at the time of legislative changes in the sector, that gave rise to the Civil Aviation Act 2000. The Act endorses an “open skies” policy of full competition on all domestic routes being permitted to use aircraft of one’s choice on these routes, subject to safety and airport capacity and capability requirements.

 

The Civil Aviation Investment Program was approved in December 2009 to address critical constraints. It comprises of a total of four tranches, with a total funding allocation of approximately $480 million. The investment program is overseeing upgrades to nineteen (19) priority national airports, supporting institutional reforms, and building public and private sector capacity, to ensure the long-term maintenance of all corresponding infrastructure. Activities completed under tranche 1 helped ensure compliance with the International Civil Aviation Organization safety and security standards for five priority airports identified under the Civil Aviation Authority’s strategic plan. Tranche 1 included (i) institutional reforms to improve air traffic services and regulatory oversights; (ii) physical works; (iii) modernization of communication, navigation, surveillance, and fire safety authority. Tranche 2 includes (i) institutional strengthening to increase the sustainability of the reformed institutions, including the National Airports Corporation, Air Services Limited, and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority; physical works; and procurement of equipment for communication, surveillance, and fire safety. Tranche 3 includes (i) institutional strengthening to increase the sustainability of the National Airports Corporation, Air Services Limited, and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority; (ii) physical works; and (iii) procurement of equipment for communication, surveillance, and fire safety.

 

Upon completion in 2019 the Civil Aviation Development Investment Program will have built or upgraded a total of thirteen (13) airport terminals and landside facilities; improved runways; taxiways and airside facilities at fifteen (15) airports; and helped secure certification from the International Civil Aviation Organization for Jackson’s International Airport. In line with the national priorities and the successful implementation of the investment program, the government has requested further investment in aviation infrastructure and corresponding support to build institutional capacity.

The transport policy will continue to be one of liberalization, recognizing that restrictions on market entry can reduce incentives for cost efficiency through lack of competition, excessive profit margins and high prices. Apart from situations where there is a need for certainty and stability of service provision, the Government will not regulate market entry on the routes and traffic to be carried by domestic transport operators. The Government will only regulate for safe operation, safe quality and fair pricing. 

 

Investment Opportunities

In summary it can be seen that in the maritime subsector the carbotage issue, a practice in which overseas vessels are prohibited from carrying domestic cargoes, is under review. Depending on the outcome of the review there is scope for further strengthening through investment opportunities.

In the air transport sector, the domestic routes are open so long as compliance requirements are adhered to such as safety and airport capacity and capabilities. With the success of ADB’s intervention in development assistance, it can be seen that there is scope for future donor funding initiatives with the government requesting further investment in aviation infrastructure including corresponding support. This means that there is opportunity for future investments in these sectors.

In recent years the Government has invested substantial budgetary support towards building and improving public infrastructure throughout the country, including regular maintenance and upkeep of the transport infrastructure.

name: MANUFACTURING
description:
Currently, Papua New Guinea imports most processed food, clothing and footwear and most of the inputs to industry and commerce. However, there are potential investment opportunities in downstream activities.


Whilst the manufacturing sector’s contribution to the national GDP maybe lower than other economic sectors of the country, the sector indeed plays a vital role in the lives of the majority of the country’s population.


The Government of Papua New Guinea has put into place strong policies which will lead to the development of a strong domestic production base to replace reliance on the non-renewable resource industries such as mining and petroleum.

The Government seeks to generate greater domestic production of most basic consumer and industry needs. As such, incentives and concessions are granted to businesses with a policy of import substitution

 

A concerted effort is being applied to address problems the industry has experienced. Infrastructure improvements and lowering of input tariffs would greatly reduce production costs. The manufacturing industry has been urged to adopt cost-reducing, efficient techniques on the factory floor and within management to prepare itself for foreign competition when protective tariffs are phased out.


The Government launched the National Manufacturing Policy 2024 aimed at raising the manufacturing sector’s GDP contribution from the current 2% to 10% in 2030.

name: Finance Sector
description:
The financial and banking services sector in PNG is open and liberal to such an extent that there are no restrictions in the industry. Financial services (banking) in PNG are regulated by the PNG Central Bank and is comprised of four commercial banks, with the locally owned Bank of South Pacific as the dominant bank. The other three commercial banks are the Australian-owned Australia New Zealand Bank; the Westpac Bank; and the locally owned Kina Bank, a relatively new entrant in the banking and financial services sector. Retail banking has grown exponentially in the country, but there is still room for improvement. Financial and banking services such as financial inclusion and mobile banking to cover the rural population have been pursued intensely. Other services provided by the financial and banking sector include savings and loans from licensed financial institutions including micro finance companies, money remitters, money changers, and foreign exchange dealers.

While most financial services are available, their supply is limited. Overseas investors may not be able to secure substantial funds locally. New operations would normally need to bring funds from overseas to establish projects.

        

INSURANCE MARKET

Insurance market is predominantly subsidiaries or branches of foreign-owned insurance companies such as QBE, AIG and Tower. The areas that these insurance companies are involved in include property, motor vehicle, marine, employer liability, medical, and brokerage. Composite insurers are mainly locally owned and underwrite life businesses. Life insurance industry is underdeveloped with only 2-5 % of the nation, businesses and people combined, having some coverage.

 

CAPITAL MARKET

Capital markets are underdeveloped with only one in existence, Port Moresby Stock Exchange, which was established in 1998 and began trading in 1999. The number of companies trading on the Port Moresby Stock Exchange as of September 2015 was nineteen (19) of which sixteen (16) are equity-listed and one debt-listed. Issues currently faced by Port Moresby Stock Exchange include liquidity and trading activity.

 

Investment Opportunities

Bank of South Pacific, PNG’s dominant domestic bank continues to look outward, expanding into regional markets with the purchase of the Westpac operations in Fiji, the Cook Islands, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga and Vanuatu. In 2018, the bank launched the BSP Finance (Cambodia) Phnom Penh to increase its regional presence, “offering not just asset finance but potentially other financial services”.

The last three years saw

In summary, the financial and banking sector plays an important role in offering a wide range of services especially in construction and building and real estate renting, which is an enterprising subsector. It can also be noted that the financial and banking sector is open and liberal, which can cater for future investments in the sector in other products. BSP’s success in entering regional markets has significant potential for expansion in the banking and financial services sector targeting overseas markets, mainly those that have a PNG diaspora and interests.

name: TOURISM
description:
Papua New Guinea is one of the most naturally beautiful countries in the world. Soaring mountain peaks, unspoiled beaches, lush rainforests, unique flora and fauna and the cultural richness of the people combine to make Papua New Guinea an increasingly popular destination for tourists.

The Government has targeted tourism as a priority area for the economic development of the country and for the creation of employment opportunities at rural and urban levels. With the Papua New Guinea Kina at a more affordable level of exchange for visitors from abroad, Papua New Guinea's many enchanting and remarkable destinations can be within the sights and budgets of many adventurers. There is already a well-established infrastructure catering successfully for many types of visitor packages but the potential for expansion and improvement is limitless.

The development and expansion of tourism in Papua New Guinea is assisted by the Papua New Guinea Tourism Promotion Authority a statutory organisation established by the Government and is well equipped with substantial industry knowledge to respond to tourism enquiries. Its activities are mainly directed at promotion and marketing of Papua New Guinea as a tourist destination and as a safe location for hospitality investment.

In line with other development policies, the Government continues to ensure the cultural, social and environmental resources of the country are safeguarded so that investment in tourism may attract some degree of interest among others.

Investment Opportunities

There is an abundance of investment opportunities in every sector of the PNG economy, including tourism. PNG has a splendid environment for the travel, writers and film crews. However, it requires wider training on world best practice to expand the tourist sites and there is room for modern technologies to be used in manufacturing of arts and crafts products.

Also, tourism requires good supporting infrastructure for its development. Investment in this area, especially roads would make PNG more attractive to its core source of tourists, as poor infrastructure is also a source of high travelling costs for tourists. The accommodation plant is generally improving in PNG, but there is still the need for more high standard accommodation facilities in most tourist attractive provinces and this constitutes opportunities for investment.

name: Petroleum
description:
There is currently a record number (over 50) of Petroleum Prospecting Licenses (PPLs) blanketing almost the entire onshore and offshore Papuan Basin and most of the North New Guinea Basin. Most of the tenements outside the Fold Belt are held by junior explorers and a number of these have signed joint venture agreements to meet their drilling commitments.


Currently there are four oil projects in the central Highlands (Southern Highlands) of PNG- Kutubu, Gobe, Moran, SE Manada and one gas project at Hides. There are many undeveloped gas fields in the country with proven and probable reserves of over 14 trillion cubic feet of gas

name: TELECOMMUNICATION
description:
The PNG telecommunications network comprises of an extensive, well-established and rapidly evolving network of microwave radio, satellite and intra-city optical fibre transmission systems that interconnect a nationwide network of telephone exchange and data switches. The network is 100% automatic, with international links to over 160 countries in the world and domestic services to all urban centres and major villages.

 

Mobile phones network, internet service and private courier services are also available.

All telecommunication licenses (operator and radio communications) as well as ensuring that provision of ICT services conform to national and international standards are the functions of the National Information and Communication Technology Authority (NICTA).


Telikom PNG is the largest national company owned by the government of PNG responsible for providing telecommunication services to the end users all throughout the country.

name: ICT Sector
description:
Sector Profile in PNG

The Information Communication Technologies (ICT) sector, for more than a decade had been inward-looking until three major policy initiatives and decisions were taken by the State. The introduction of mobile services; the implementation of the Competition Act in March 2007; and the formulation of the National Information Communication Technology Policy. With the finalization of the ICT Policy in 2008, the National Information Communications Technology Authority (NICTA) Act was introduced by the Government in 2009, taking on the responsibilities of the Telecommunications Act 1996 and the Radio Spectrum Act 1996. This move resulted in the decommissioning of all roles and functions of the Papua New Guinea Telecommunications Authority (PANGTEL) and transferred to NICTA, with the policy objective of NICTA to regulate the ICT sector.

 

With these reforms in place, cheaper prices and stronger competition was experienced in the country and this also ushered in a new generation of innovative services in the business landscape. For instance, when the Irish-based Digicel company entered the local mobile market in 2007, the sector experienced the benefits of increased competition. Mobile call rates (prices) were significantly reduced and there has been an increase in, and expansion of, network coverage to 89 of the country’s population. The innovative services emanating out of the mobile market and network coverage include, but are not limited to, clients of the PNG Power being able to pay for electricity using their mobile phones as well as the local Bank of South Pacific introducing and rolling out internet and banking services to the individuals and business communities, especially those in the rural communities.

 

In terms of a national broadband network, an undersea cable (the Coral Seas Cable System) will be laid between Sydney (Australia) and Port Moresby (PNG) and onward to Solomon Islands. It is a project funded by the Australian Government on two thirds one third basis, and only applies to the Sydney hub to Port Moresby (and to Solomon Islands). The project is valued at PGK 324 million (A$136 million) and has a technical maximum capacity of 10 terabytes per second, which is about 1000 times the current capacity. The domestic internet network will be built by China’s Huawei company, which will connect the undersea cable running between Port Moresby, Alotau, Popondetta, Lae and Madang provinces. After completion, the cable system will be owned by both the PNG and Solomon Island Governments, respectively.

 

Investment Opportunities

There is a need for investment in the ICT sector to reduce the rates of connection to the internet, which range from K15 to K30 per hour.

2G still exists in many rural and remote areas, with 3G and 4G LTE centered more on urban areas. Hence there is a need to provide enhanced access to the interne to the bulk of the population in the rural areas.

Internet access is expected to improve with the 2018 build-out of a new submarine cable known as the Coral Sea Cable System which will link PNG to the Solomon Islands, with a connecting cable to the Australian (Sydney) landing station. It is expected to provide increased capacity and reliability as well as reduce Internet costs for consumers. Investors in the commercial telecommunications services would be desirable to help realize the full potential of this new submarine cable.

There is also an opportunity for investment in Kumul Telikom to revamp their communication services on NGN and also for NICTA to regulate the licenses/spectrum to protect PNG’s asset from internal and external attacks. This would result in reduction in cost of service and improvement in quality.

name: Agriculture
description:
Agriculture has been of immense importance and will always remain the backbone of Papua New Guinea sustenance with over 85 percent of the population involved in subsistence farming. The moderate tropical climate with high levels of seasonal rainfall is highly favourable for agricultural activities.

The driving force behind commercial agriculture in Papua New Guinea has always been the export crops namely coffee, cocoa, coconut (copra), oil palm and kernels.

There's been a significant increase in the cash crop business giving rise to the sector's export portfolio.

Specific investment opportunities dwell in coffee, oil palm, cocoa, copra, whilst other minor export commodities include spices, tea and rubber.

Agriculture has the potential to significantly support economic growth and tackle many of PNG’s developmental challenges. By helping subsistence smallholder farmers transition into commercial and semi-commercial agriculture, more jobs can be created.

This will reduce monetary poverty, increase the affordability of essential services, and address factors contributing to fragility and crime. It will also help to boost growth and decrease dependence on the resource sector.

name: MINING
description:
Papua New Guinea has been a gold exporter since the 1930s and has ranked as the 11th largest gold producer in the world over the last few years. Papua New Guinea also ranks 10th in the world in terms of copper production, and has a very real potential to exceed the present production level. Also, silver is a commercial by-product from most of the mines. Papua New Guinea has extensive reserves of natural gas and oil.


 The main mineral deposits are copper, gold and sliver but there are also recoverable deposits of other minerals such as nickel and cobalt. Papua New Guinea currently operates several world class mines in terms of production and operating cost performance. They include;

 

  • Ok Tedi Copper-Gold Mine
  • Ok Tedi Mining
  • Porgera Gold Mine
  • New Porgera Limited (Barrick Gold, Zijin Mining, KMHL)
  • Ramu Nickel-Cobalt Mine
  • Metallurgical Corporation of China (MCC)
  • Lihir Gold Mine
  • Newmont Corporation
  • Simberi Gold Mine
  • St Barbara
  • Hidden Valley Gold Mine
  • Harmony Gold
  • K92 Gold Mine
  • K92 Mining


The economy has benefited from large ongoing development expenditure at a number of projects including the Morobe Mining Joint Venture (Hidden Valley) in the Morobe Province, Allied Gold (Simberi), in the New Ireland Province and the New Guinea Gold (Sinivit) in the East New Britain Province.


Alluvial Mining

In addition to several mechanised alluvial mining projects, there are about 60,000 small-scale gold miners, who work as individuals, family or clan groups in Papua New Guinea. Small-scale mining is estimated to produce about four tonnes of gold annually.

Although gold and copper have formed the foundation for PNG's mining industry in the past, the country's mineral endowment is far more extensive. The prospects for other minerals has led a number of companies to target a range of other mineral resources including chromite, nickel, iron, platinum-group metals and industrial minerals.
